text: We float over a large corporate office, a grid of cubicle slides under us, perfect, symmetrical-- EMPLOYEES working desks, milling in and around the cubicles-- We slide toward the outside walls-- light bathes in from windows, reflections curve off glass-dividers, setting of the nicer offices--

One of the nicer offices, glassed-in-- at the desk: JOHN HUME, 40's-- tie, shirtsleeves, glasses perched-- company man, polished, not overly-so-- pores over spreadsheets, marking them up-- The spreadsheets-- columns of numbers arc, graceful-- Joh sifts through decimal-chains, crossing out-- shakes his h then: he sees something, a pattern in the chains-- he cir a long rising line-- half smiles-- We see headings: DEATHS, NATURAL; DEATHS, MISHAP; CHILD
FATALITY CLAIMS PAID, DENIED-- he circles another chain--

(quietly-- amused) Huh-- there you go-- John looks up-- AMY, his assistant, the EMPLOYEES out on floor, working, joking, all ages, men, women-- happy, bus numbers-- KEVIN-- 30, appears at his door, file in hand--
Bother you? John-- back at his numbers-- smiles--
Just when you think there's no order anywhere, there's order looking right at you-- Kevin-- not following--
Oh-- right-- John looks at Kevin's file, Kevin brings it-- John scans-
What do you need, here?

Annie said I need you to approve this, no beneficiaries, wife dead-- no kids-- easy-peasy-- John looks up, on easy-peasy-- he doesn’t sign it-- close the file, pushes it-- KEVIN (cont'd) But-- there's no estate-- the lawyer's got dementia--
I saw that. So-- what do we do?
(galled) Don't make me file with the state-- for a twenty-five-hundred dollar policy? John bristles-- Kevin sees it--
We file with the state. So one day, in the unlikely event somebody looks back at this guy's death, they'll know we did our job.
(scoops up the file) Oh-- we cover our asses, duh-- got it, sorry--
No-- we do our job. Kevin-- chastised-- John smiles-- JOHN (cont'd) And we cover our asses for when the illegitimate children show up--
(looks ) I didn't see-- illegitimates--

Well, illegitimate children will leap into being and sue us pantless if you don't give enough of a shit about their dad to put on record that we in the office of life and death made an effort to pay somebody twenty-five hundred bucks in compensation for his passing-- John picks up his spreadsheet again-- smiles at Kevin-- JOHN (cont'd) -- lest he die in vain. OK? (back in his numbers) Might even make some poor bastard feel better. Kevin-- excused-- hesitates, nods at the spreadsheets--
What's the order-in-the-universe thing? John-- poring over it--

We spent three hundred thousand bucks for these guys to make us this new model, new field-data, new society, who-dies-when-and-how-- but they screwed up all the decimal weights. It's three-hundred thousand bucks worth of dogshit-- Kevin-- following as best he can-- JOHN (cont'd) But even so, it says people with kids live longer than people with no kids, people with two live longer than people with one-- (flipping pages) Smoking is bad-- speeding is bad. Divorce is bad. Deaths in the family are bad. John smiles--  JOHN (cont'd) It's nice to see all that crap's still true. If you have twenty kids, anyway. So you'd better drive home under the speed-limit and get busy with that.
(smiles) I've got my illegitimates. John-- benign teacher-- he’s dismissed--

And aren't they the lucky tykes? Kevin goes-- John, back to his numbers-- he glances up, e catches the PHOTO on his desk-- HELEN, his wife, 30's, beautiful, sharp-eyed, as smart as him, or smarter-- TWO BOYS-- BRENDAN, the older, LUCAS, t younger-- John looks at the picture-- contented--

A prep-school office, rolling fields, fall trees outside- LUCAS, 14-- a couple of years older-- and more pissed-off than in his picture-- sits in front of the dean's desk, waiting-- the dean isn't there-- A WELL-DRESSED WOMAN steps across, putting a file back in cabinet-- she turns, sits at the desk-- It's HELEN-- LUCA
Of course it isn't fair, but when you screw up, it's embarrassing-- I'm supposed to be a dean--
It's not like I killed somebody.
Telling a teacher to shove it is as close as we get here.
The guy's a buffoon, Mom, I was quoting-- it was like an ironic shove it.

You want an ironic probation? Lucas doesn't answer-- looks out the window-- KIDS are running track, outside, he watches them loop-- HELEN (cont'd) We haven't even gotten to the home punishment, this is the school-end-- Lucas-- winces-- stares out the window-- she watches him- HELEN (cont'd) So-- what do we do? Lucas-- still looking out: A BUNCH OF OLDER BOYS cuts acr the track, bags, hockey-sticks slung-- BRENDAN, 16, Lucas older brother, with them-- laughing, jocky-- golden-boy--
(still out the window) Anything but community-service.

(smiles, mock-amazed) Luke, that's brilliant-- community service is a great idea-- He rolls his eyes-- HELEN (cont'd) The assisted-living home's having a dance party, they need help-- you know-- Leisure World--
For the love of God, Mom-- Seizure World?
(smiling-- benign torture) OK-- hockey team needs a laundry boy-- you could help your brother out, support the team-- Lucas looks out, at Brendan and his crew, strutting, goof
I'll take the dance of the dead. I can man the diaper-station. Helen-- cheerfully tough-- loving, if he cared to notice- notices-- isn't going to admit it--
Last time, OK? Lucas-- it’s a fair bust-- he smiles, barely, nods-- Hele takes it-- exhales-- HELEN (cont'd) Thank you. Very much.

BRENDAN-- with other PLAYERS, skating sprints up the ice, COACH WALDREN watching-- Brendan shoots along the ice, guiding the puck like it's glued to his stick, fast-- effortless-- aggressive-- the whistle blows-- everybody stops, except-- Brendan-- He keeps skating-- the coach blows the whistle again-- Brendan spins to a stop, breathing hard, smiling--

Who wants to start on Saturday, in beautiful Roxbury? They wait-- trick-question-- he looks at his list-- COACH WALDREN (cont'd) (reading off) Larkin, Hume, Tomacek, Whelan-- Brendan-- smiles on 'Hume'-- nods--
A nice old colonial, rambling kitchen-- HELEN, BRENDAN, LUCAS, at the table, eating--
Yeah, because you're a kiss-ass--
Hey--
(laughs) I got the skills, that's all-- God gave me the skills--
(to Helen) Mom, I need to go kill myself, can I be excused? Helen-- heard it before-- clearing her plate, putting foo from the pots into containers--
Of course you do, Lukey--
I've got a cretin for a brother--
I've got a no-dick for a brother--
(sharply, to Lucas) OK-- you stop, right now-- (to Brendan-- softer) And you should know better. Luke catches the softer voice for Bren-- used to it--
(all innocence, to Helen) What? Helen, back to the leftovers-- shaking her head--
Let's be a family, shall we?

(snorts, laughing) Do I get to say no? (bangs the table, yelling) I demand emancipation-- I want a lawyer, I'm filing, right now-- Brendan-- smacks Lucas on the head, not too hard-- Helen- another warning-look--
EXT. HUME’S HOUSE - DRIVEWAY - NIGHT JOHN pulls up-- but the driveway’s blocked by TRASH-CANS- gets out, drags them aside-- glaring at the neighbor's ho

INT. HUME’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - NIGHT Helen's still looking at the boys, coming off her warning shot-- the front-door bangs closed-- Helen-- smiles despite herself-- JOHN comes in, coat, briefcase-- exhausted--
I missed dinner? Helen-- dumps the containers back into the pots--
No, there's-- plenty--
(to John) I need a ride to Southie Saturday.
Southie?
Roxbury-- it's an exchange game. I'm starting again.
(beaming) That's fantastic-- Waldren loves you, huh? Lucas sees the glow on John-- like Lucas isn't in the roo anymore-—
Yeah, 'cause he's a kiss-ass-- John nods-- he approves, in this case--
Well, good for him-- we all going? He bumps Helen aside, gently, loads a plate--
Luke's got soccer.
But I'm not even starting, so--

You should kiss some more ass. Or not suck so bad-- Lucas flips Brendan the finger-- John bristles, looks at Helen-- Lucas-- knows he went too far-- Brendan-- steps i covers for Lucas-- BRENDAN (cont'd) Come on Dad-- he's kidding-- he's being an idiot-- Lucas-- grateful-- John looks to Helen-- she does this al day--
(to Brendan-- benign) Don’t call him an idiot-- (to Lucas) Lucas-- you have a loyal and loving brother--
(he smiles) Loyal loving kiss-ass-- Brendan laughs-- John-- tired and hungry--
Let's be civilized, or I'll kill somebody. Fair? Brendan scrunches Lucas by the back of the neck-- Lucas shrugs him off, goes-- Brendan shoves him ahead--
Whatever, weasel--
(mimics, dumb-jock voice) Uhhh, whatever, weasel-- John watches them go, Helen dumps leftovers-- again--
See what you miss when you don't come home?  10. He nods, smiles--

They stopped throwing food. She nods-- smiles-- rinsing dishes-- he watches her-- JOHN (cont'd) I can do those. She drops the dish she's holding, grabs a wine-bottle, po two glasses, sits-- day's end--
Lukey told Roger Perle to shove it. They look at each other, dead-serious-- then-- John start laughing-- cracking up-- she does too--
Didn't you tell that guy to shove it last year? She's laughing harder, trying not to-- nodding--
It was so hard to punish him without laughing--
He's your son alright-- She bursts out laughing, louder, nodding, John too-- she looks to the door, tries to stop-- they fall quiet, final she sips her wine, shakes her head--
Two boys. No justice. He smiles at her-- they look at each other--

CROWD of blue-collar and white-collar PARENTS, hooting, yelling-- COACH WALDREN at the benches, intent-- JOHN-- i the stands, watching as-- BRENDAN-- like he was born on the ice, dodges DEFENDERS, drives forward, weaving-- he feints, shoots-- GOAL-- the score clicks up on the board-- the crowd's yelling--  11. John, stamping his feet, clapping, hooting-- he smiles, watching Brendan gliding on the ice, beaming-- He skates away, John watches-- his jersey-- 'HUME' in red letters, big ‘11’-- Brendan shakes his stick high, crowd roars again-- John smiles, shakes his head-- proud-- tickled--
Late in the day, light waning-- it's a crummy area, proje slum-tenements, wasteland-lots-- far cry from Arlington-- JOHN, driving, BRENDAN, riding, smiling-- good day--
(watching the streets) Some of the guys have been talking about college in Canada--
(driving-- smiles) We're thinking about college? Don't you have another birthday before we think about college?
‘Plan for success,' Dad--
(impressed) I said that? That's excellent advice. Brendan doesn't answer-- John watches the road-- JOHN (cont'd) Canada. Canada's-- far--
(smiles) You'll still have Lukey.

There's a comfort-- Brendan winces, protective-- John catches it, smiles--  JOHN (cont'd) You had a very good game today. You've had a few good games. But professional hockey, Bren-- that what we're talking about? Brendan shrugs-- nods-- JOHN (cont'd) -- that's a high-risk business.
This is from your extensive professional sports background--
My extensive risk assessment background. Risks-- liabilities-- the stuff of life, son--
Stuff of your life-- exactly--

(smiles) Don't make fun of your father. Brendan falls silent-- wasted streets slide by-- JOHN (cont'd) Well-- let's look at this-- you have a talent, I don't dispute that. Let's evaluate it, like any asset, see how far you can take it-- in a business-way. Brendan looks at him-- JOHN (cont'd) I can talk to Coach Waldren. We can research schools-- in Canada if we have to-- find somebody who can-- educate us on hockey versus, say-- law-school--
Educate us? Dad, I just want to play some hockey--
(he smiles) I'm saying we can look into it.

Brendan gets it-- nods-- smiles-- JOHN (cont'd) Just don't tell Mom. Brendan-- grins, laughs-- John rounds a corner, looks ahe stumped-- searching-- JOHN (cont'd) Where the hell's the damn expressway? No signs-- just dark, shabby streets, half-industrial, housing projects beyond-- an alarm pings-- John looks-- a flashing orange gas-pump on the dash-- JOHN (cont'd) Great-—— John looks around the bleak streets-- feels tension, biti then-- he sees the lights of a gas station-- eases, sligh JOHN (cont'd) (goofing, like a general) We may be lost, men, but we'll have gas, by God-- onward to petroleum-- Brendan laughs-- they pull in--
JOHN pulls up to the pump, lights from a convenience stor glare-- John looks around-- wary of the neighborhood--
JOHN gets out, squints at the pump-- BRENDAN gets out too starts for the convenience-store-- John stops--
Where do you think you're going?
(smiles) Need my fluids, Dad-- John looks around-- wary-- but-- no obvious danger--
Ahh-- the obligatory slushy-stop--  14.
They have 'em in there, right?

That, or something worse for you. You have money? Brendan starts across-- John punches buttons on the pump- JOHN (cont'd) In and out, OK? We have to get home-- Brendan smiles, walking backward, half-way there-- John p the pump in the tank, keeps an eye on Brendan until he disappears inside the store-- we glimpse him, pumping slu John laughs, quiet, shakes his head-- pulls out his phone speed-dials, gets Helen's voice-mail-- JOHN (cont'd) (on cell) Just letting you know your son's gone to Canada to play hockey. We didn't want to drag out goodbyes, so I left him at the airport. He'll call us. If he can. Of course, we may never see him again, but as long as he's happy, right? He pauses-- cars flash by-- a big truck rolls in-- JOHN (cont'd) Home soon. He closes his phone, scans the street-- a strange hush fa a loose sheet of newspaper scuds across the street, twirl upward-- it catches John’s eye, he follows its motion--

Behind John-- wheels whining-- cars cornering fast-- John turns, sees: two pimped-out muscle cars rounding the corner, pulling up to the convenience-store-- John’s guard goes up-- his eyes flick to the store, he se BRENDAN-- paying-- sipping the slushy-- John’s eyes flick back to the muscle cars-- he can barely heads inside through black-tint windows-- arms going up-- like they're pulling masks _on-- John’s eyes go wide-- as  15. GANG-BANGERS in black ski-masks burst out of the cars-- g in hand-- charge toward the store-- John-- his eyes widen in fear, shock-- He charges forward, knocks right into the gas-hose, knock loose, it sprays him-- he clambers past, frantic, looking

BANGERS burst in-- hold guns at Brendan, the CLERK-- Bren wide-eyed-- as a tall banger-- BILLY DARLEY-- the leader, scoops cash out-- the clerk reaches for an alarm, Billy swings his gun and shoots him in the chest-- then, same instant, smacks a scrawny banger-- JOE, his little brothe on the back of the head, hard--
(smacking the scrawny one) Do it, you faggot--

JOHN-- running forward blindly, eyes on Brendan-- a car pulling in to pumps clips him, knocks him to the concrete he scrambles up, another car pulls out, barely misses crushing his head as he stumbles, runs-- as:

JOE-- jittery-- scared-- eyes in his mask full of fear, h Brendan-- staring-- terrified-- BILLY (cont'd) Do it-- (grins, at Brendan-- yells) Ready, kid? You ready? John-- running-- hears Billy yell-- rushes up as: Joe-- like mean liquid, turns-- walks to Brendan, snake-f = pulls a LONG MACHETE from his jacket-- and slashes the blade up, across Brendan's throat-- gashing it open--
JOHN-- sees-- in horror-- as:  16. Brendan-- stares-- staggers out, toward John-- falls thro the door-- drops--

JOHN-- charges toward Brendan-- BRENDAN-- throat _open-- lying on the concrete-- blinking gasping-- JOE-- stares down at Brendan-- amazed, or terrified, at t sight-- what he's done to him-- BILLY and the other BANGERS charge through the door, scat except: Joe-- he sees John-- hesitates-- machete in hand- Joe-- runs for the street-- passes near him-- John lurche tries to grab him-- he gets him by the throat, throws him down-- he drops his machete-- John gets his mask off-- se his face-- as-- The BANGERS stop-- look back at John and Joe-- Heco start for Joe, to help, Billy holds him back-- smiles, not yet- lets Joe struggle-- JOHN-- smacks Joe into the concrete-- trying to get free get to Brendan-- Joe swipes at him-- John bangs him down- JOE-- finally-- gets his weight out from under John, flip up, throwing John down on the concrete, smashing John’s h against it-- John falters, almost blacking-- Joe jumps up jumps over John-- runs for the cars, but-- Billy jumps in-- engines ripping, cars shoots backward-- Joe runs to them but the cars peels out without him-- Joe runs out into the street, looks back at John-- And is smacked by a pick-up truck-- spun by impact, Joe sprawls on black-top, out cold-- traffic stops, horns hon John-- on the concrete, barely conscious, blood drips in eyes-- he blinks it away-- Brendan's motionless-- white-- John crawls to him-- fadin takes Brendan’s body in his arms, screaming--
(screaming) Help-- help me--

We see into the two muscle-car speeding away, racing, sid side-- the bangers peel off their masks, we glimpse: BILL 20's, Boston Irish-trash, hard as cross-nails-- BODIE, bl hard-timed, hard-eyed-- HECO, Salvadoran, silver bead on lower lip, chin jutting-- BAGGY, Cuban, head shaved-- SPI and JAMIE, Irish-trash, DOG and TOMMY, black, jailhouse-m all pumped-- whooping-- Bodie looks back--
Where’s your brother?
(laughs-- callous) He's a man now-- he can take the subway-- They cackle-- speed away, whooping--
A burst of activity-- Brendan wheeled into the ER, JOHN, agonized, trots by Brendan’s side as ORDERLIES rush him i

In slow motion without sound: looking down a hospital corridor, we see a distraught HELEN and LUCAS run up to J The ER DOCTOR approaches, talks to them-- we can’t hear-- Helen collapses into John, sobbing, shaking-- John holds tears well out of him but he doesn’t break down, his face stone-- Lucas, stunned, left-out-- FADE TO BLACK.

text: JOHN-- bandaged-- staring through one-way glass-- a group Irish-trash STREET-RATS squint in the glaring light-- JOE among them, under a big ‘6'--  18. John stares at Joe-- runty-- malevolent-- in a dead-dream DETECTIVE WALLIS, 50's-- waits-- John breathes--
Six. Number six.
(nods) Joe Darley.
He's a-- kid--
He's a runt, almost twenty. And he's an animal. John stares at Joe, a trapped rat-- hate boiling up--
Bleak. Raining. Cold. The HUMES watch as their first-born is lowered into the ground-- John watches the casket-- no tears-- he’s far from Luke, from Helen--

Empty, silent kitchen-- we hear the front door close, off JOHN, in a funeral-suit, comes in, turned to stone, dry-e HELEN and LUCAS-- shell-shocked, follow-- none of them se to know why they've gone in there-- Helen begins to cry, leans back against a counter, suppre the tears-- she looks to John-- but he's locked-in-- sile Lucas-- sits at the table, looks at both John and Helen-- neither of them seems to notice him--

I'll make some eggs. Helen-- doesn't answer-- John drapes his jacket on a chai goes to the fridge, gets eggs out, starts making them--  19. Helen watches him-- sits next to Lucas-- they sit in sile as John scrambles the eggs-- finally-- Helen looks down at her black dress-- picks at it.
I should probably change. She looks to John for a response, there isn't any-- she g up, goes-- finally Lucas gets up--
(to John) I guess I'll change too. Nobody answers Luke-- John whisks the eggs-- Lucas watche him a moment-- and goes--

(quietly-- after Lucas is gone) OK. John looks up, sees Luke's gone-- he stands there, stirri the eggs-- Suddenly-- he slams the pan across the stove, eggs splatt out, burn on the flame-- He stares at the mess-- grabs a towel, cleans it up-- sta a new batch.
JOHN and HELEN, in bed, in the dark, unable to sleep--
They said there's a-- pre-trial hearing tomorrow, they want me to go. Make a statement or something. Do-- you want to go with me? She stares-- fighting pain--
You go. Put that-- animal in jail.  20.
That's what the cop called him, an animal-- John-- trying to make order-- JOHN (cont'd) Some kind of-- mad dog. Helen stares into the dark-- she takes a breath--
The school said they wanted to do a memorial-- at the next game. The team wanted to do something. John-- it's cold comfort.
That's-- nice of them.

(she nods) He would have been playing. Helen closes her eyes-- reaches for John’s hand-- he take it, she squeezes it, as hard as she can, crying, softly, trying not to-- weary of crying-- John holds her hand--
LUCAS-- in bed, awake-- staring too-- He gets out of bed-
LUCAS comes into Brendan's room-- stands in the doorway, staring at it-- posters, his bed, books, his hockey-stuff He stays, a moment-- lays his hand on the bed-stead-- goe
John hears LUCAS walk by their door, back to his room-- h hears Luke's door close again-- he doesn't move--
JOHN, on his way to court-- sees empty TRASH-BARRELS righ behind his car, blocking the way-- he looks across to:
BAKER, the neighbor, rushing back, obviously the culprit- glares at John-- righteous, annoyed--
(yells over) You're supposed to take them in-- John glares-- drags the barrels aside--
LUCAS-- staring at his desk as MR. PERLE, 40's, drones, b

-- there may not be much actual justice, but if the code said ‘an eye for an eye' carved right into a big stone slab, they could say, look, it's in writing-- Lucas-- rubbing his knuckles on the desk, distracted-- MR. PERLE (cont'd) (in bg) -- don't riot, don't rebel, keep Slaving in the pyramids, watch hieroglyphic cable'-- Lucas rubs harder, the skin opens, starts to bleed-- A GIRL next to him sees-- he looks at his hand-- surprise HENNING-- a 'friend,' callow-- snickers-- Perle looks bac  22. MR. PERLE (cont'd) My friend Mr. Hume-- (not without sympathy) Joining us today? Luke sits up-- picks up his pen-- HENNING looks, ridiculi
Chill, Humey-- Lucas stares-- seething--
HELEN, trying to work, looks out-- the HOCKEY TEAM, stick their shoulders, all very like Brendan-- she looks at her files-- and gently but firmly shoves them off the desk--
JOHN-- with MICHAEL BARING, ASSISTANT DA, 40's-- with som JUNIOR DA's, and DETECTIVE WALLIS--

Today's easy-- John looks at Baring-- it isn't easy for him-- BARING (cont'd) I need you to sit there, put the fear of God in this guy-- if the judge asks you to, you tell him what you told us, and identify Darley in court-- John, nods-- BARING (cont'd) The minute I get your statement in, with you sitting right there, the public defender's going to wet his pants and fold, I'll make a deal in five minutes, get this guy in jail today-- easy-peasy-- John-- stares at Baring--  23.
What the hell are you talking about? What deal? I want this guy in jail-- for the rest of his life--
No-- I can get you three-to-five, guaranteed-- that's a very decent result in the-- John-- outraged--
He killed my son-- Baring-- blinks-- sympathetic, but-- overwhelmed--

Guaranteed time-- not maybe, not the jury didn't feel up to it-- that's worth more than chasing a make-believe ten-to-life and the guy walks free-- you want that? John-- furious-- ready to jump out of his chair--
You aren't using my son's death for a card-trick-- do you understand? Baring-- wishes it were otherwise--

Mr. Hume-- this is what my office is willing to do. I'm fighting a pattern here, initiation killings are just part of it, I get a banger off the street a year or so, somebody does my job for me, he never comes out alive, fine with me, he finds Jesus, fine with me-- John-- missing something--
What do you mean-- initiation killing? JI thought it was a robbery-- Wallis shrugs-- uncomfortable--  24.
It just looked like one. It was an initiation-- you kill someone at random, to get made in a gang. It's the-- price of admission.

You're saying my son was murdered so some asshole could feel like a man? So he could be in some club? Wallis-- Baring-- look at John-- he stares, numbly-- stun JOHN (cont'd) There's-- no sense to that-- John-- shock slips to-- rage-- growing second by second-- Baring-- sorry, but:
This is a take it or leave it thing, Mr. Hume. Sorry to say. John-- stares at Baring--
JOHN-- on the stand-- he looks at: JOE and his public defender, WILSEY, 30's suit, pony-tail-- BARING standing-
Your Honor, I'd like to enter the statement of a witness present at the attack-- father of the victim-- The judge glances at John-- at the clock--
We can enter that at trial, can we not, Mr. Baring?

I believe your honor, if we enter the statement today, defense will change their plea to guilty and save the people the time and expense of a trial-- The judge looks at John again-- John’s staring at Joe-- t judge waves Baring to the bench--  25.

That's the statement? Baring brings John's statement, the judge looks at it-- John's still looking at Joe-- JUDGE GOULD (cont'd) Mr. Hume, you're giving evidence that Mr. Darley here, before your eyes, attacked your son and caused his death? You’re saying you'll testify to that in a trial? John-- staring straight at Joe--
No sir. I am not.
What? John looks at Baring-- Joe's starting to smile--
There were a lot of them. It was dark. I can't be sure any more. Baring-- furious-- Joe-- grinning like a coyote-- John st at him--
Do you expect to obtain evidence other than Mr. Hume's here? Baring-- dead-ended--
No your Honor. I do not. The judge-- skeptical-- but nowhere to go--

I'm dismissing this case-- I humbly note you might have been better off taking your chances with a jury, Mr. Baring-- John stares at Joe as the judge talks-- JUDGE GOULD (cont'd) (to Joe) You are released from custody.  26. You may return with a bailiff to the holding cells to retrieve your personal effects. Joe gets up-- struts out, right by John, smiling-- John watches him go--

Winds blowing-- colder weather moving in-- JOE-- carrying a plastic bag of personal effects-- talkin his cell, laughing-- hunching in his jacket from the cold ACROSS THE STREET -— JOHN-- in his car, staring at Joe-- eyes burning into him Joe sits on a bus-stop bench-back, waiting-- John watches him-- glances in his rear-view-- Brendan's g bag, his hockey stick-- still in the back seat-- he looks it, a moment-- then looks ahead as: The muscle cars pull up-- BILLY the others, pile out, laughing, smacking Joe around, he laughs-- they do a sort leering cheer, roasting him--
(we just hear, from across) You fucked that up pretty good, huh? Who's aman, now? Joe laughs-- all cocky, now--

That fucker was sitting in a pool of pee, man-- that’s right I’m walking, pucker the fuck up-- John-- seething-- stares at their faces-- Billy-- Bodie, Heco, all of them-- he knows who they are-- JOE-- gets in they pull away-- John watches the muscle cars go-- he hesitates-- breathin hard-- and starts his car-- follows--

JOHN-- following the cars-- deeper and deeper into the Southie war-zone-- he catches glimpses of JOE, through th window-- The neighborhood turns darker, more ragged-- closer to th part of town where Brendan was killed-- John follows, watches-- finally-- they pull up, JOE gets Billy and the others are grinning--
A GIRL-- waiting on the step of the decrepit project buil she pulls a little vial out of her pocket, shakes it, grinning-- BILLY and the others shove him forward, laughi

Have a nice time, weasel-- Billy smiles-- goes to her-- she and Joe kiss as the cars pull away-- JOHN-- parked up the street-- watching-- She pulls Joe’s keys out of pants for him-- they go in-- door of the building closes behind Joe-- John stares at the door-- leans his head on the steering wheel, lost-- no idea what to do-- He sits up, gripping the wheel with all his might-- start the car, finally-- pulls away--

John pulls up-- jumps out of the car-- starts looking aro the garage-- he scans the tools hanging on the walls-- He picks up a weeding spade, grabs it-- puts it down agai he opens a locker-- an axe-- he hefts it-- not right, dro it-- He reaches up to a top shelf-- straining-- pulling down a dusty plastic tool-tub-- riffling through, loudly--  28. LUCAS has come out-- he stands at the door, watching John
Hey-- John stops, briefly-- then--
(searching again) Hey-- Lucas keeps watching him--
What are you doing? John pulls out a large scythe-- hefts it--

Nothing-- son-- John scans the garage for another weapon-- he drops the scythe back in, we see: a half-rusted old hunting-knife-- dirty, dull-- but deadly enough-- John takes it in his ha Lucas watches John, not seeing what’s in John’s hands-- h picks up a box-cutter from the tool-bench, fiddles with i John sees-- JOHN (cont'd) Don’t play with that-- put it down-- Lucas puts it back-- thinking--
So-- it was like a gas-station? John stops-- agitated-- LUCAS (cont'd) Where Bren got killed-- John-- thrown-- on edge-- covering--
Yes. It was a gas-station-- (he hesitates) Why do you want to know? Lucas doesn’t know himself-- trying to make sense of it--  29.
I wondered where he died. John-- not what he wants to talk about now-- but--
